facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 279 of 1967 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated September 15, 1966 of the Allahabad High Court in Second Appeal No. 222 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 279 of 1967. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated September 15, 1966 of the Allahabad High Court in Second Appeal No. 222 of 1960.

facts.text: There are two appeals by Special Leave against the Judgment and decree of a learned Judge of the Allahabad High Court allowing a plaintiff's second appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Beg, J. There are two appeals by Special Leave before us, Leave, against the Judgment and decree of a learned Judge of the Allahabad High Court allowing a plaintiffs second appeal

facts.text: Government of Rampur gave the plaintiff a house under the orders of His Highness the Nawab of Rampur passed on 23rd June, 1945.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs case was that the Government of Rampur had given him a house under the orders of His Highness the Nawab of Ramur, passed on 23rd June, 1945.

facts.text: Rampur State merged with Uttar Pradesh in 1949, becoming a district of Uttar Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that, after the merger of Rampur State in Uttar Pradesh in 1949, when Rampur became a district of Uttar Pradesh, this house was given by the Government of Uttar Pradesh

facts.text: Government of Uttar Pradesh gave the house to the Municipal Board of Rampur, the Defendant-Appellant.

anchor.surface_text: this house was given by the Government of Uttar Pradesh to the Municipal Board of Rampur, Defendant-Appellant, which demanded rent from the plaintiff by numberice.

facts.text: Municipal Board of Rampur demanded rent from the plaintiff by notice.

anchor.surface_text: Defendant-Appellant, which demanded rent from the plaintiff by numberice. On the plaintiffs refusal to pay, the house was attached on 23rd February, 1955.

facts.text: On plaintiff's refusal to pay rent, the house was attached on 23rd February, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: On the plaintiffs refusal to pay, the house was attached on 23rd February, 1955. The plaintiff deposited a sum of Rs. 100- under protest.

facts.text: Plaintiff deposited Rs. 100 under protest.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff deposited a sum of Rs. 100- under protest. He then filed his suit, on 26-10-56, for a declaration that he is the owner

facts.text: Plaintiff filed suit on 26-10-1956 for declaration of ownership in possession of the house or alternatively licensee entitled to remain in possession for life without rent.

anchor.surface_text: He then filed his suit, on 26-10-56, for a declaration that he is the owner in possession of the house, and, in the alternative, that he is a licensee entitled to remain in possession of the house for life without payment of rent

facts.text: Defendants denied the alleged gift of ownership or life-interest in the house to the plaintiff.

anchor.surface_text: The defendants, the State of Uttar Pradesh, the Municipal Board of Rampur, and the Public Work. Department at Rampur, denied the alleged gift of either the ownership or of a life-interest

facts.text: Defendants claimed no relationship of landlord and tenant between plaintiff and defendants.

anchor.surface_text: They also pleaded that there was numberrelationship of landlord and tenant between the plaintiff and the defendants.

facts.text: Defendants claimed permission to reside was valid only while plaintiff was in service of former ruler of Rampur.

anchor.surface_text: Their case was that, if any permission to reside in the house was given to the plaintiff by the ruler of the State of Rampur before the merger of Rampur with Uttar Pradesh, it was valid and effective only so long as the plaintiff was in the service

facts.text: Defendants claimed damages for use and occupation as rent at Rs. 10 per month from 1-4-1953 to 30-1-1954.

anchor.surface_text: They set up a claim to damages for use and occupation in the form of rent from the plaintiff at Rs. 10/- per month from 1-4-1953 to 30-1- 1954.

facts.text: Plaintiff's licence, if any, terminated on merger of Rampur with Uttar Pradesh according to defendants.

anchor.surface_text: According to them, the plaintiffs licence, if any, automatically terminated when the State of Rampur merged with the State of Uttar Pradesh.

facts.text: Trial court and first Appellate Court found plaintiff did not prove claims after examining evidence including order dated 23rd June 1945 (Exhibit 1) and letter dated 30th June 1949 (Exhibit A-10).

anchor.surface_text: The Trial companyrt as well as the first Appellate Court bad found, after ,in examination of all the evidence, including the alleged order dated 23rd June 1945, of His Highness the Nawab of Rampur  Exhibit 1 , a letter dated 30th June 1949 ,Exhibit A-10

facts.text: Allahabad High Court Judge reversed findings of courts below, holding Nawab's order of 23rd June 1945 as valid gift conferring ownership per Mahomedan law.

anchor.surface_text: A learned Judge of the Allahabad High Court had, upon the plaintiffs second appeal, reversed the companycurrent findings of fact recorded by the Courts below because the learned Judge thought that the order of the Nawab of Rampur dated 23rd June 1945, companystituting a valid declaration of a gift

facts.text: Plaintiff was described as Nigran Shikar Mahi or Supervisor of Fishing.

anchor.surface_text: we find that it is only a piece of information sent. to the plaintiff who is described as Nigran Shikar Mahi or Supervisor of Fishing.

facts.text: Previous occupant of the house was a mechanic occupying without rent with Nawab's permission.

anchor.surface_text: He said that its previous occupant, a mechanic, was also occupying it, without payment of any rent, with the Nawabs permission.

facts.text: Supreme Court found the transaction was a grant of a revocable license, not a gift of corpus or usufruct for life.

anchor.surface_text: we are satisfied that the plaintiff failed to, prove either a grant of the companypus or of the usufruct of the house to him for his life by its owner. The transaction before us would amount to numberhing more than the grant of a license

facts.text: No mutation in Municipal records showing transfer of ownership.

anchor.surface_text: No evidence was given of any mutation in a Municipal record showing transfer of ownership of the companypus for which the term milkiyat is used.

facts.text: Plaintiff produced Agha Khan, Assistant Military Secretary of Nawab, who signed and sent the communication.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff himself had produced Agha Khan, the Assistant Military Secretary of the Nawab of Rampur, who had signed and sent the companymunication, set out above, to the plaintiff.
